page.title: 04Everyday Life in Salem
page.content: Until the spate of new housing in the village(Golwg y Gar, and main street), Salem was traditionally Welsh, and thus followed a tradional way of life, the children speaking little but Welsh until starting school. The original families still keep to the Welsh way, their main meal being dinner at midday with tea at four (Welsh cakes and bara brith) and supper in the evening. The incoming families, because the man works away from home, eat dinner in the evenings, and rarely take tea or supper. These families do not attend the chapel, but usually churches out of the district, and so the chapel is in decline. Salem chapel is Welsh non- conformist (Annibynwyr). It now has 32 members, average attendance 20, and is used only twice monthly. All other chapels in the area are now closed.
